title: Simple serialization format for logging and analytics in Go
Description: Usage, design and implementation of simple serialization format for logging and analytics in Go.

inline_content.Text: Description: Usage, design and implementation of simple serialization format for logging and analytics in Go.

title: I was looking to save multiple records with somewhat flexible schema to a file. Go has plenty of options but I couldn’t find anything that was just right.

inline_content.Text: I was looking to save multiple records with somewhat flexible schema to a file. Go has plenty of options but I couldn’t find anything that was just right.

c

title: csv - efficient but uses fixed records; not very readable if there are many fields on a single line

inline_content.Text: csv - efficient but uses fixed records; not very readable if there are many fields on a single line

title: protocol buffers - binary so unreadable; needs up-front scheme

inline_content.Text: protocol buffers - binary so unreadable; needs up-front scheme

siser
a
https://github.com/kjk/siser
(which stands for Simple Serialization).

title: It’s a typical key/value serialization with one neat feature: support for large data (e.g. an image or long text).

inline_content.Text: It’s a typical key/value serialization with one neat feature: support for large data (e.g. an image or long text).

title: The format is line oriented. Each line is
${key}: ${value}\n
c

inline_content.Text: The format is line oriented. Each line is

title: If the value is larger than 120 bytes or is not ascii text (with bytes outside of 32-127 range), I serialize it as large value:

title: I use this format for 2 main purposes:

inline_content.Text: I use this format for 2 main purposes:

title: structured logging to help in debugging

inline_content.Text: structured logging to help in debugging

title: When used for analytics, each record represents an event. I save the events to a file and later on process the whole file record-by-record and calculate desired statistics.

inline_content.Text: When used for analytics, each record represents an event. I save the events to a file and later on process the whole file record-by-record and calculate desired statistics.

title: Here’s a
full example
a
https://github.com/kjk/blog/blob/b18317d3dbde1d21745aaea615d952f2c2e158c8/visitor_analytics.go#L108
of calculating basic daily statistics on HTTP requests (most frequently visited pages, most frequent 404s, most frequent referrers).

title: The library doesn’t offer marshaling directly to/from structs. Could be added with a bit of reflection.

inline_content.Text: The library doesn’t offer marshaling directly to/from structs. Could be added with a bit of reflection.

title: It doesn’t directly support non-string types like
int
c
or
time.Time
c
. You have to convert them to/from string yourself.

inline_content.Text: It doesn’t directly support non-string types like
. You have to convert them to/from string yourself.

title: Some implementation decisions were made with performance in mind.

inline_content.Text: Some implementation decisions were made with performance in mind.

title: Given key/value nature of the record, an easy choice would be to use
map[string]string
c
as argument to encode/decode functions.

inline_content.Text: Given key/value nature of the record, an easy choice would be to use

title: However
[]string
c
is more efficient than a
map
c

. A slice can be reused across multiple records. We can clear by re-slicing as empty slice and reusing underlying array. A map would require allocating a new instance for each record, which would create a lot of work for garbage collector.

inline_content.Text: . A slice can be reused across multiple records. We can clear by re-slicing as empty slice and reusing underlying array. A map would require allocating a new instance for each record, which would create a lot of work for garbage collector.

title: When serializing, you need to use
Reset
c
method to get the benefit of efficient re-use of the record.

inline_content.Text: When serializing, you need to use
method to get the benefit of efficient re-use of the record.

title: The format avoids the need for escaping keys and values, which helps in making encoding/decoding fast.

inline_content.Text: The format avoids the need for escaping keys and values, which helps in making encoding/decoding fast.

title: How does that play out in real life? I wrote a
benchmark
a
https://github.com/kjk/siser/blob/6ffab5b5c5f0fa60f5f4b203a776af7930d2850b/serialize_test.go#L171
comparing siser vs.
json.Marshal
c
. It’s about 30% faster:

inline_content.Text: How does that play out in real life? I wrote a

title:
$ go test -bench=.
BenchmarkSiserMarshal-8          1000000          2108 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONMarshal-8            500000          3181 ns/op

BenchmarkSiserUnmarshal-8         500000          2908 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONUnmarshal-8          200000          7482 ns/op

content_resolved.code:
$ go test -bench=.
BenchmarkSiserMarshal-8          1000000          2108 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONMarshal-8            500000          3181 ns/op

BenchmarkSiserUnmarshal-8         500000          2908 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONUnmarshal-8          200000          7482 ns/op

title: The format is binary-safe and works for serializing large values e.g. you can serialize png image

inline_content.Text: The format is binary-safe and works for serializing large values e.g. you can serialize png image

title: It’s also very easy to implement in any language.

inline_content.Text: It’s also very easy to implement in any language.
